Yesterday, PubPeer [won a near-complete victory](http://retractionwatch.com/2015/03/05/judge-rules-most-of-pubpeers-commenters-can-remain-anonymous/) in a case seeking the identities of their commenters. And also yesterday, a Massachusetts judge struck down — for the second time — a [request by Mario Saad to remove expressions of concern about four of his papers in Diabetes](http://retractionwatch.com/2015/03/05/researcher-asks-court-to-overturn-motion-denying-his-request-to-quash-expressions-of-concern/). Psychology has been home to some of the most infamous cases of fraud in recent years, and while it's just a few bad apples who are spoiling the bunch, the field itself has seen an overall increase in retractions, according to a new paper by [Jürgen Margraf](http://www.kli.psy.ruhr-uni-bochum.de/klipsy/team/en/klipsy-en-prof.dr.j.margraf.html) appearing in [Psychologische](http://psycontent.metapress.com/content/120238/) [ Rundschau](http://psycontent.metapress.com/content/120238/) and titled " [Zur Lage der Psychologie](http://psycontent.metapress.com/content/c1147l50700253p4/)." That increase, Margraf found, is not entirely due to its most well-known fraudsters. Here's the relevant figure: since 1989: study](https://retractionwatch.com/2015/03/05/psychology-retractions-have-quadrupled-since-1989-study/#more-26241) [Diabetes researcher won't give up court fight to expressions of concern](https://retractionwatch.com/2015/03/05/researcher-asks-court-to-overturn-motion-denying-his-request-to-quash-expressions-of-concern/) Apparently, you can't keep [Mario Saad](http://retractionwatch.com/category/by-author/mario-saad/) down. The researcher, who had [12 figures in a paper corrected this week](http://retractionwatch.com/2015/03/04/plos-one-mega-correction-but-no-retraction-for-researcher-who-sued-diabetes-journal/), was dealt a setback last week when a judge [denied his motion to remove expressions of concern on four of his papers in the journal Diabetes, ](http://retractionwatch.com/2015/02/25/judge-denies-motion-by-researcher-to-quash-diabetes-expressions-of-concern/)saying that would have amounted to prior restraint — essentially, censorship (a no-no, thanks to the First Amendment). Saad and his attorneys, however, were undeterred. Stephanou takes the blame for the "errors" which felled the Journal of Cell Science paper, about how a tumor suppressor responds to DNA damage. Here's the [notice](http://jcs.biologists.org/content/128/5/1064?etoc) for "STAT-1 facilitates the ATM activated checkpoint pathway following DNA damage:" [Continue reading Prominent geneticist David Latchman's group notches second retraction](https://retractionwatch.com/2015/02/27/prominent-geneticist-david-latchmans-group-notches-second-retraction/#more-26188) [Are retractions more frequent in stem cell research?](https://retractionwatch.com/2015/02/26/are-retractions-more-frequent-in-stem-cell-research/) [There are a number of fields that seem to punch above their weight on Retraction Watch: ](https://i0.wp.com/retractionwatch.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/sci-eng-ethics.jpg) [Anesthesiology](http://retractionwatch.com/category/by-subject/clinical-study-retractions/anesthesia-retractions/), home to the and [psychology](http://retractionwatch.com/category/psychology/), home to [Diederik Stapel](http://retractionwatch.com/category/diederik-stapel/) and others. But the red-hot field of [stem cell research](http://retractionwatch.com/?s=%22stem+cell%22) is another that makes frequent appearances, last year's [STAP controversy](http://retractionwatch.com/2014/07/02/stap-stem-cell-papers-officially-retracted-as-nature-argues-peer-review-couldnt-have-detected-fatal-problems/) being particularly prominent. There's an interesting (but unfortunately paywalled) recent paper in Science and Engineering Ethics, " [The Acid Test for Biological Science: STAP Cells, Trust, and Replication](http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11948-015-9628-2)," by [Cheryl Lancaster](https://www.dur.ac.uk/chmd/staff/lancaster/), a small part of which tries to answer that question. Lancaster applies the same methods [Fang, Steen, and Casadevall](http://www.pnas.org/content/109/42/17028.full) used to broadly measure the causes of retractions in all life science and biomedicine to the specific field of stem cell research: [Continue reading Are retractions more frequent in stem cell research?](https://retractionwatch.com/2015/02/26/are-retractions-more-frequent-in-stem-cell-research/#more-26147) [Judge denies motion by researcher to quash Diabetes expressions of concern](https://retractionwatch.com/2015/02/25/judge-denies-motion-by-researcher-to-quash-diabetes-expressions-of-concern/) American Diabetes Association 1, Mario Saad 0. As [reported by the National Law Journal](http://www.nationallawjournal.com/id=1202718837081/Judge-Refuses-to-Muzzle-Medical-Journal-in-Defamation-Case), a federal judge in Boston has denied Saad's requests to stop the ADA's flagship journal, Diabetes, from publishing expressions of concern about four of Saad's papers, and to prevent the journal from retracting the studies. Saad [filed suit against the ADA on February 5](http://retractionwatch.com/2015/02/09/diabetes-researcher-sues-journal-stop-retractions/).
